context: revision rhinoplasty and left conchal cartilage harvest to correct nasal deformity.
preoperative diagnosis: nasal deformity, status post rhinoplasty.
this patient is an otherwise healthy male who had a previous nasal fracture.
during his healing, perioperatively he did sustain a hockey puck to the nose resulting in a saddle-nose deformity with septal hematoma.
during his healing, perioperatively he did sustain a hockey puck to the nose resulting in a saddle-nose deformity with septal hematoma.
the patient healed status post rhinoplasty as a result but was left with a persistent saddle-nose dorsal defect.
the patient did have approximately 12 ml of lidocaine with epinephrine 1% with 1:100,000 infiltrated into the nasal soft tissues.
in addition to this, cocaine pledgets were placed to assist with hemostasis.
at this point, attention was turned to the left ear. approximately 3 ml of 1% lidocaine with 1:100,000 epinephrine was infiltrated into the subcutaneous tissues of the conchal bulb.
the patient did have very broad lower lateral cartilages leading to a bulbous tip.
the patient did have very broad lower lateral cartilages leading to a bulbous tip.
the patient had medial and lateral osteotomies performed with a 2-mm osteotome.
the patient had a series of double-dome sutures placed into the nasal tip.
a gore-tex small implant had been selected, previously incised.
next, attention was turned to performing a columella strut.

at the termination of the case, the ear was inspected and the position of the conchal cartilage harvest was hemostatic. there was no evidence of hematoma, and the patient had a series of brown steri-strips and aquaplast cast placed over the nasal dorsum.
he was charged to home on antibiotics to prevent infection both from the left ear conchal cartilage harvest and also the gore-tex implant area.
